articles.headline: ‘Crusty’ and ‘Pillowy’: How N.Y.C.-Style Bagels Made It Big in London
articles.snippet: Bakeries selling big, doughy bagels have opened to rave reviews in Britain, but some traditionalists are standing by the London “beigel.”
articles.abstract: Bakeries selling big, doughy bagels have opened to rave reviews in Britain, but some traditionalists are standing by the London “beigel.”
articles.lead_paragraph: “What’s an ‘everything bagel?’”

articles.headline: This Man Turned the Worst Job in College Basketball Into a Slam Dunk
articles.snippet: South Carolina Salkehatchie had no budget, players or running water in the locker room when Matt Lynch arrived. One season in, the first publicly gay head coach is figuring out how to win, on the court and off.
articles.abstract: South Carolina Salkehatchie had no budget, players or running water in the locker room when Matt Lynch arrived. One season in, the first publicly gay head coach is figuring out how to win, on the court and off.
articles.lead_paragraph: A little over a year ago, the University of South Carolina Salkehatchie posted a job opening for its men’s basketball coach. It might have been a single sentence: applications being accepted for the worst college coaching job in the country.

articles.headline: The 10-Year-Old Boy Who Has Become the Face of Starvation in Gaza
articles.snippet: The harrowing image of a skeletal Yazan Kafarneh circulated widely on social media and has served as a graphic warning about the enclave’s dire food situation.
articles.abstract: The harrowing image of a skeletal Yazan Kafarneh circulated widely on social media and has served as a graphic warning about the enclave’s dire food situation.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is all too easy to trace the skull beneath the Gazan boy’s face, the pallid skin stretching tight over every curve of bone and sagging with every hollow. His chin juts with a disturbing sharpness. His flesh has shrunk and shriveled, life reduced to little more than a thin mask over an imminent death.
articles.byline: By Bilal Shbair, Vivian Yee and Aaron Boxerman

articles.headline: How Fraudsters Break Into Social Security Accounts and Steal Benefits
articles.snippet: Thousands of people receiving Social Security benefits have had their money diverted into criminal accounts. Here’s what to know.
articles.abstract: Thousands of people receiving Social Security benefits have had their money diverted into criminal accounts. Here’s what to know.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past two decades, Liz Birenbaum’s 88-year-old mother, Marge, has received her Social Security check on the second Wednesday of each month. It’s her sole source of income, which pays for her room at a long-term care center, where she landed last October after having a stroke.

articles.headline: Lily Gladstone for Best Actress? Oscars Gamblers Are Betting Big.
articles.snippet: Inside the world of people making bets on the winners of the Academy Awards — with some taking home thousands of dollars.
articles.abstract: Inside the world of people making bets on the winners of the Academy Awards — with some taking home thousands of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Oscars.

articles.headline: How Trump’s Justice Dept. Derailed an Investigation of a Major Company
articles.snippet: The industrial giant Caterpillar hired William Barr and other lawyers to defuse a federal criminal investigation of alleged tax dodges.
articles.abstract: The industrial giant Caterpillar hired William Barr and other lawyers to defuse a federal criminal investigation of alleged tax dodges.
articles.lead_paragraph: In December 2018, a team of federal law enforcement agents flew to Amsterdam to interview a witness in a yearslong criminal investigation into Caterpillar, which had avoided billions of dollars of income taxes by shifting profits to a Swiss subsidiary.

articles.headline: Toyota’s Hybrid-First Strategy Is Delivering Big Profits
articles.snippet: Toyota, the world’s largest automaker, has been criticized for selling few electric vehicles, but its decision to focus on hybrids is paying off financially.
articles.abstract: Toyota, the world’s largest automaker, has been criticized for selling few electric vehicles, but its decision to focus on hybrids is paying off financially.
articles.lead_paragraph: In today’s high-tech, high-stakes auto industry, fortunes can change quickly, and there’s no better example of that right now than Toyota Motor.

articles.headline: BMW Is a Surprise Winner in Electric Vehicles
articles.snippet: Once considered a laggard, the German luxury carmaker is one of only a few established automakers that has been able to compete effectively against Tesla.
articles.abstract: Once considered a laggard, the German luxury carmaker is one of only a few established automakers that has been able to compete effectively against Tesla.
articles.lead_paragraph: As BMW car bodies glided down an assembly line in Munich recently, showered by sparks from robotic welders, it was hard to tell which vehicles would be powered by batteries, fuel-burning engines or both. In the view of many analysts, that is not a good thing.

articles.headline: The Surprising Left-Right Alliance That Wants More Apartments in Suburbs
articles.snippet: The YIMBY movement isn’t just for liberals anymore. Legislators from both sides of the political divide are working to add duplexes and apartments to single-family neighborhoods.
articles.abstract: The YIMBY movement isn’t just for liberals anymore. Legislators from both sides of the political divide are working to add duplexes and apartments to single-family neighborhoods.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, the Yimbytown conference was an ideologically safe space where liberal young professionals could talk to other liberal young professionals about the particular problems of cities with a lot of liberal young professionals: not enough bike lanes and transit, too many restrictive zoning laws.

articles.headline: With Haiti in Chaos, a Humanitarian Crisis Is Rapidly Unfolding
articles.snippet: As gangs have united in concerted attacks against the state, the prime minister is stranded in Puerto Rico, and food, water, fuel and medical care are in short supply.
articles.abstract: As gangs have united in concerted attacks against the state, the prime minister is stranded in Puerto Rico, and food, water, fuel and medical care are in short supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Ronald V. LaRoche has not been able to cross into dangerous territory to inspect the hospital he runs in Haiti’s Delmas 18 neighborhood since it was ransacked by gangs last week, but a TikTok video he saw offered clues to its current condition: It was on fire.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles, David C. Adams and Andre Paultre

articles.headline: Elon Musk Has a Giant Charity. Its Money Stays Close to Home.
articles.snippet: After making billions in tax-deductible donations to his philanthropy, the owner of Tesla and SpaceX gave away far less than required in some years — and what he did give often supported his own interests.
articles.abstract: After making billions in tax-deductible donations to his philanthropy, the owner of Tesla and SpaceX gave away far less than required in some years — and what he did give often supported his own interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before March 2021, Elon Musk’s charitable foundation had never announced any donations to Cameron County, an impoverished region at the southern tip of Texas that is home to his SpaceX launch site and local officials who help regulate it.
articles.byline: By David A. Fahrenthold and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: Wyoming Banned Abortion. She Opened an Abortion Clinic Anyway.
articles.snippet: The only abortion clinic left in the state has been protested and set on fire, rebuilt and opened as Wyoming grapples with what it means to be conservative in a post-Roe nation.
articles.abstract: The only abortion clinic left in the state has been protested and set on fire, rebuilt and opened as Wyoming grapples with what it means to be conservative in a post-Roe nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was not such an implausible idea, back in 2020, when a philanthropist emailed Julie Burkhart to ask if she would consider opening an abortion clinic in Wyoming, one of the nation’s most conservative states and the one that had twice given Donald Trump his biggest margin of victory.

articles.headline: One Year After Bank Crisis, a Struggle Over What Needs to Change
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse last March set the stage for a clash between bankers and their regulators.
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse last March set the stage for a clash between bankers and their regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, the government and America’s largest banks joined forces in a rare moment of comity.

articles.headline: As Israel’s Ties to Arab Countries Fray, a Strained Lifeline Remains
articles.snippet: The United Arab Emirates has maintained its links to Israel throughout the war in Gaza, but the relationship, built on a U.S.-brokered deal, is under pressure as anger against Israel grows.
articles.abstract: The United Arab Emirates has maintained its links to Israel throughout the war in Gaza, but the relationship, built on a U.S.-brokered deal, is under pressure as anger against Israel grows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a few years ago, plenty of citizens of the United Arab Emirates were willing to speak warmly about their country’s budding ties with Israel.

articles.headline: Dispute Over Gaza War Heats Up Between Biden and Netanyahu
articles.snippet: The Israeli prime minister rejected a rebuke from the U.S. president over the scale of the Israel assault.
articles.abstract: The Israeli prime minister rejected a rebuke from the U.S. president over the scale of the Israel assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after President Biden asserted that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was “hurting Israel more than helping Israel,” Mr. Netanyahu dismissed that contention as “wrong,” escalating the leaders’ increasingly public dispute.
articles.byline: By Vivek Shankar, Raja Abdulrahim and Andrew Jacobs

articles.headline: Navigating Israeli Restrictions, Many Palestinians Find It Hard to Reach Al Aqsa
articles.snippet: Muslim access to the mosque compound has long been a point of contention as Israel has exerted tighter control.
articles.abstract: Muslim access to the mosque compound has long been a point of contention as Israel has exerted tighter control.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the sermon about the Muslim holy month of Ramadan sounded over the speakers from Al Aqsa Mosque, 13-year-old Yousef al-Sideeq sat on a bench outside the compound’s gates.

articles.headline: Ukraine Could Deploy F-16s as Soon as July, but Only a Few
articles.snippet: Countries promised the fighter jets last year, but delivering them and training pilots have proved complex. Ukraine may start with as few as six, out of about 45 pledged.
articles.abstract: Countries promised the fighter jets last year, but delivering them and training pilots have proved complex. Ukraine may start with as few as six, out of about 45 pledged.
articles.lead_paragraph: The jets are ready, and the flight instructors are waiting, at a new training center in Romania that was created to teach Ukraine’s pilots to fly the F-16 warplane. But there’s a catch: The Ukrainian pilots have yet to arrive, despite declarations last summer that the center would play a crucial role in getting them into the air to defend their country from increasingly deadly Russian strikes.

articles.headline: Automakers Are Sharing Consumers’ Driving Behavior With Insurance Companies
articles.snippet: LexisNexis, which generates consumer risk profiles for the insurers, knew about every trip G.M. drivers had taken in their cars, including when they sped, braked too hard or accelerated rapidly.
articles.abstract: LexisNexis, which generates consumer risk profiles for the insurers, knew about every trip G.M. drivers had taken in their cars, including when they sped, braked too hard or accelerated rapidly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenn Dahl says he has always been a careful driver. The owner of a software company near Seattle, he drives a leased Chevrolet Bolt. He’s never been responsible for an accident.

articles.headline: Biden’s Budget Underscores Divide With Republicans and Trump
articles.snippet: The president’s $7.3 trillion budget proposal for the next fiscal year includes about $3 trillion in deficit reduction over a decade, largely from raising taxes on high earners and corporations.
articles.abstract: The president’s $7.3 trillion budget proposal for the next fiscal year includes about $3 trillion in deficit reduction over a decade, largely from raising taxes on high earners and corporations.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden proposed a $7.3 trillion budget on Monday packed with tax increases on corporations and high earners, new spending on social programs and a wide range of efforts to combat high consumer costs like housing and college tuition.

articles.headline: How the A.I. That Drives ChatGPT Will Move Into the Physical World
articles.snippet: Covariant, a robotics start-up, is designing technology that lets robots learn skills much like chatbots do.
articles.abstract: Covariant, a robotics start-up, is designing technology that lets robots learn skills much like chatbots do.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies like OpenAI and Midjourney build chatbots, image generators and other artificial intelligence tools that operate in the digital world.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Balazs Gardi
